importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico in Handlova, Slovakia, where Juraj Cintula shot at him.
The date of the final verdict by the Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica, which sentenced Cintula to 21 years in prison.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the attack occurred and the initial investigation began, marking the beginning of public and political turmoil in Slovakia.
The duration of the trial, which spanned from July 2024 to October 2025, highlighting the legal and societal significance of the case.

keyTakeAways: Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old pensioner and former mine worker, was found guilty of terrorism charges in connection with an attempted assassination of Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.

Cintula shot at Fico five times from a distance of just over one meter during a public greeting in Handlova, resulting in serious injuries to Fico, including wounds to the abdomen, hip, hand, and foot.

The Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica ruled that the attack constituted terrorism due to its targeted nature against a political leader, citing Cintula's stated motive of opposing Fico's policies on Ukraine, media, and culture.
Cintula claimed he wanted to stop Fico from continuing policies he believed damaged Slovak freedom and culture, describing the act as a 'scream against fear that is paralyzing the society'.
The verdict was less than the maximum life sentence, and Cintula has stated he will appeal, calling the sentence 'unjust'.

The case exposed deep societal and political divisions in Slovakia, with Fico blaming the opposition for fostering anger, while the opposition accusing Fico of undermining democratic standards, media freedom, and covering up corruption.
Fico, who has remained in public office since the attack and returned to work, has expressed forgiveness toward Cintula despite the severity of the incident.
The trial underscored tensions between populist governance and liberal democratic values, especially regarding the role of public officials and political violence.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court sentenced Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, to 21 years in prison for terrorism charges related to an attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024. The attack, which occurred during a public gathering in Handlova, left Fico seriously injured. The court determined that Cintula’s act constituted terrorism due to its targeted nature against a political leader, citing his stated opposition to Fico’s policies on Ukraine, media, and culture. The verdict reflects deep societal divisions in Slovakia, with Fico blaming the opposition for societal anger and the opposition accusing him of undermining democracy. Despite the conviction, Cintula plans to appeal, claiming the sentence is unjust. Fico, who has continued in office and expressed forgiveness, remains a central figure in the national political landscape.
title: Slovakia court sentences suspect in attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 years
